page.title: 17BRATTLEBY CONTINUED
page.content: The park land behind the old Manor House comprises 29 acres and still clearly shows the old ridge and furrow style of farming dating back to the Normans. The furrows run across the field both dividing the ridges and draining the ground. The water from them ran into a mill race. Some evidence of this mill race is still to be seen. Archeologists have discovered the remains of an earlier group of plaster and wood houses in the park and a short distance away stood a Roman Villa and shards of pottery have been discovered. In the park are a herd of cattle. The trees, all planted by the ancestors of Mr. Wright are a mixture of evergreens and decidous some them very old and the trunks of a wide girth. The walls surrounding the park were made from the stone from the old farm yard.
